security: This document reveals the immediate reactions and intelligence assessments of the CIA regarding Fidel Castro and other Cuban officials following President Kennedy's assassination. Disclosing these initial reactions and assessments could reveal the CIA's intelligence gathering capabilities and sources, potentially compromising ongoing operations or relationships with foreign entities. For example, it states: "The Cuban defensive military alert, ordered immediately after the news of President Kennedy's death, remains in effect..." and "The chargé of the Cuban Embassy in Chile says there is no doubt that CIA or 'other Yankees' assassinated the President..."
summary: A CIA daily summary reports on Cuban reactions to President Kennedy's assassination, including Fidel Castro's speech suggesting ultrarightists may have been responsible and the Cuban military's defensive alert.
summary_one_paragraph: This Top Secret CIA daily summary, dated November 25, 1963, details Cuban reactions to President Kennedy's assassination, with Fidel Castro delivering a two-hour speech expressing apprehension that US policy toward Cuba may become harsher and insinuating that ultrarightists in the US were exploiting the event, possibly even being responsible for it, to promote a more aggressive stance against Cuba; the summary also notes the continuation of a Cuban defensive military alert ordered after Kennedy's death, the Cuban chargé in Chile blaming the CIA or "other Yankees" for the assassination, and Che Guevara warning Cubans of a potential threat to world peace due to reactionary forces in the US.
title: Daily Summary: Cuban Reactions to President Kennedy's Assassination
sender: Central Intelligence Agency (Office of Current Intelligence)
